author: FPJ Bureau
title: Experience the “Charismatic Coonoor”
text:
Experience the “Charismatic Coonoor” Experience the “Charismatic Coonoor” — By FPJ Bureau | Aug 20, 2015 05:49 pm As we continue our travel diaries of the serene South India, we come across another lesser known creation of Mother Nature- Coonoor. This astounding beauty is situated in the Nilgiris District, Tamil Nadu, India. It is at an altitude of 2000 ft above the sea level and is 17 km from Udhagamandalam which is a hill station. In order to reach Coonoor you can take planes to Coimbatore Airport which is 70 km from Coonoor. If you’re traveling by rail you can take the Nilgiri Mountain Railway service. Coonoor is blessed with shades of greenery at every step. It is a mixture of nature and modern art which is showcased in the range of tourist attractions it has to offer. From places known as Dolphin’s nose to Lamb’s Rock we bring to you the best places to visit in Coonoor. Sim’s Park A very popular place to visit is the Sim’s Park which is a garden spread over 12 hectares and consists of over 1000 species of plants which include magnolia, pines, tree ferns, and camellia. The garden has a Japanese touch to its style and received its name from J. D. Sim, the secretary of the Madras Club in 1874. The annual fruit and vegetable show is held here which is a famous attraction of the park. Sim’s Park Picture credits: ar-ar-blog.blogspot.com Dolphin’s Nose Viewpoint It is situated 12 km from Coonoor near Tiger Hill. The viewpoint provides an amazing panoramic view of the vast Nilgiri Hills and Catherine Falls which will leave you jaw dropped. The best time to take a glimpse of this place is early morning as the sky paints this picturesque beauty with misty clouds giving it a heavenly touch. Dolphin’s Nose Viewpoint Picture credits: www.indiantravels.com Lamb’s Rock It lies on the way to Dolphin’s Nose. It is another vantage point with a fabulous scenic appeal due to its tree and coffee plantations. It is situated around 8 km from Coonoor Bus Stop. The best time to visit here is from January to March as the plants bloom making this place a colorful destination. Lamb’s RockPicture credits: asiantravelsooty.com Droog Fort For those who wish to go back in time and take in the beauty of the history of Coonoor head over to Droog which is at a distance of 13 km from Coonoor. The place is basically fort runs, wherein the actual masterpiece belonged to Tipu Sultan in the 18 th century. It has turned out to be a popular tourist destination which is best known for a number of bird species around the fort. Droog FortPicture credits: www.oddroad.com Hidden Valley 
This place is off the travel map and to get here you need to take the trek route across lush greens and forests. The journey is what makes the valley a fruitful place to visit. There are no mainstream routes to this place but it offers the best views for a nature lover. It is situated beyond the Wellington Golf course. So buckle up to experience on of the best excursions here at the Hidden Valley. Hidden ValleyPicture credits: www.facebook.com/BEAUTIFULCOONOOR Coonoor has a fresh, green and dewy terrain and that brings us to know its magnificent waterfalls which attract tourists with their glorious beauty. The primary beauties are Law’s Falls, St. Catherine’s Falls and Katary Falls. Law’s Falls It is located 10 km from Coonoor and is set along the forest that stretches around undisturbed. It is named after Col. Law who constructed the new Coonoor Ghat. It is a small waterfall around 30 ft but attracts many during the monsoon when it flows with its all might and strength. Law’s FallsPicture credit: www.buzzntravel.com St. Catherine’s Falls 
These majestic falls are located at a height of 250 ft and are a popular destination for tourists. The name is derived after the wife of M.D. Cockburn who introduced coffee plantation in Kotagiri. The waterfall is situated 5 km from Coonoor on the way to Mettupalayam. St. Catherine FallsPicture credits: hdimagegallery.net Katary Falls The main reason for it to gain fame is for the fact that it is a power station which supplies 1000KW near Selas. It is said to be the third largest waterfall in the Nilgiris. It is situated at Kundha road and attracts hundreds of visitors to capture the roaring milky waters of Katary with a height of 180 m. Katary FallsPicture credits: www.worldwildwonders.com
